references.title: Lactobacillus GG has in vitro effects on enhanced interleukin-10 and interferon-gamma release of mononuclear cells but no in vivo effects in supplemented mothers and their neonates

characteristics.name: Notes
characteristics.value:
Sponsor: supported by the University of Freiburg and by Infectopharm, Heppenheim, Germany.

Declaration: not reported.

characteristics.name: Methods
characteristics.value: Double-blind, randomised, placebo-controlled prospective trial.

characteristics.name: Participants
characteristics.value:
Inclusion criteria: pregnant women with:

  • an uneventful pregnancy;
  • absence of underlying chronic disease; and
  • a family history of atopic disease: 1 family member (mother, father, or older sibling) with AD, allergic rhinitis, or asthma and a confirmed allergic sensitisation against an inhalant allergen.

Exclusion critiera: none stated.

characteristics.name: Interventions
characteristics.value:
Treatment (n = 54): L. rhamnosus GG (ATCC 53103) containing 5 x 109 cfu daily for 4 – 6 weeks before expected delivery. Capsules taken post-natally for 6 months. Directly after delivery, breastfeeding mothers took the capsules; otherwise, children received the agents (n = 2 in the LGG group, n = 3 in the placebo group). After 3 months, capsules were given only to the neonates.

Control (n = 51): placebo (microcrystalline cellulose).

Duration of breastfeeding: median treatment 9 months, control 8 months.

characteristics.name: Outcomes
characteristics.value:
Primary outcome: prevention of atopic diseases during the first 2 years of life.

Other outcomes: severity of atopic dermatitis, the cumulative incidence of atopic dermatitis, the incidence of recurrent (5 episodes) wheezing bronchitis, total immunoglobulin E (IgE) and the number of children with sensitisation to an inhalant allergen at the age of 2 years.


Definitions: questionnaires and blinded physician examination. Physicians underwent standardised training program.
Eczema confirmed by pruritus, facial or extensor involvement, or both, and chronic relapsing course by using United Kingdom Working Party criteria (William 1994). The criterion (quote:) “chronic relapsing course” fulfilled if child had eczema for 1 month. The severity scoring of atopic dermatitis (Scoring Atopic Dermatitis Index) was used to assess eczema severity.
Skin prick tests, sensitisation to inhalant allergens and total IgE performed at 2 years reported for all infants.

risk-of-bias.domain: Bias due to deviations from intended interventions
risk-of-bias.support-for-judgement:
Placebo used (microcrystalline cellulose). LGG and placebo capsules were made identical in appearance, taste, smell and packing. The physicians who conducted the physical examinations and diagnoses of atopic disease were unaware of the contents of the capsules until the end of the study.

Per-protocol analysis.

risk-of-bias.domain: Bias due to missing outcome data
risk-of-bias.support-for-judgement: 11/105 (10.5%) withdrew from the study during the follow-up or were excluded from the analysis because of major protocol violation. No details for the reason of drop-out were detailed.

risk-of-bias.domain: Bias in measurement of the outcome
risk-of-bias.support-for-judgement: The primary end point was the manifestation of an atopic disease at the age of 2 years. Specific definitions for allergy reported. Primary outcomes were measured by validated and appropriate methods.

risk-of-bias.domain: Bias in selection of the reported result
risk-of-bias.support-for-judgement: No pre-specified analysis plan. UKF00505.

risk-of-bias.domain: Overall bias
risk-of-bias.support-for-judgement: The study is judged to have some concerns for multiple domains in a way that substantially lowers confidence in the result.

risk-of-bias.domain: Bias arising from the randomization process
risk-of-bias.support-for-judgement:
Blocks of 4 according to a computerised randomisation list. Computer randomised and blinded. Allocation concealment was not described.

No significant differences at baseline between groups in family history of atopy.

references.authors: Niers L, Martín R, Rijkers G, Sengers F, Timmerman H, van Uden N, et al
references.title: Correction for: Niers et al. The effects of selected probiotic strains on the development of eczema (the PandA study)

characteristics.name: Methods
characteristics.value: Double-blind, randomised, placebo-controlled trial.

characteristics.name: Participants
characteristics.value:
Inclusion criteria: pregnant women and their families were included at least 2 months before expected delivery (n = 156).

Families with a positive family history of allergic disease, i.e. atopic eczema, food allergy, asthma or allergic rhinitis in either the mother, or the father plus an older sibling with a history of allergic disease.

Exclusion criteria: if their mother received antibiotic treatment during the last 2 weeks of pregnancy, child born before 37 weeks' gestation, children received antibiotic treatment in the first 2 weeks of life, if ingestion of the study product was difficult because of vomiting or feeding problems in general for longer than 3 weeks from birth, or if the children had other major medical problems.

characteristics.name: Interventions
characteristics.value:
Probiotic bacteria were prenatally administered to the pregnant mothers during the last 6 weeks of pregnancy and postnatally for 12 months to their offspring. The intervention was mixed with at least 10 ml of water, breast milk or infants' formula, depending on the choice of feeding by the parents, and ingested as a suspension.

Intervention group (n = 78): once daily 3 x 109 cfu (1 x 109 cfu of each: B. bifidum W23, Bifidobacterium lactis W52 (previously classified as Bifidobacterium infantis), and Lc lactis W58) freeze-dried powder of the probiotic mixture.

Control group (n = 78): placebo consisting of the carrier of the probiotic product, i.e. rice starch and maltodextrin. Breastfeeding treatment group 84%, control group 79%). Mean duration of breastfeeding treatment group 7.0 months, control group 7.2 months.

characteristics.name: Outcomes
characteristics.value:
Primary outcome: development of eczema during the first 2 years of life, and the initial effects on early microbial colonisation and immune responses. Symptoms indicative of food allergy, eczema, asthma and allergic rhinitis at age of 3, 12 and 24 months were evaluated.

Other outcome: compliance and problems experienced with the daily administration of the study product. 6 year follow-up study included the preventative effect of probiotics on the prevalence of asthma, allergic rhinitis and eczema in these high risk children. 

Definitions: Parental reported eczema from diaries completed weekly.

Physician diagnosed eczema was defined as eczema reported by the parents and diagnosed as eczema by the family doctor or consulted physician.
Eczema was defined as non-infectious dermatitis with typical features (redness, dryness, oedema, oozing and itching (scratching)) and distribution.

Atopic eczema was defined as eczema plus sensitisation, i.e. detectable (> 0.35 IU/ml) allergen specific IgE antibodies or a positive SPT.

6 year follow-up study included diagnosed allergic diseases from the treating family doctor, complete physical examinations, blood sampling and lung function testing. 
Asthma was defined as at least 1 of the following 4 criteria: doctors diagnosed asthma active in the past 12 months, parental reported wheezing in the past 12 months, use of asthma medication in the past 12 months or an at least 9% reversibility in the forced expiratory volume in half a second (FEV 0.5) or in one second (FEV1).
Allergic rhinitis was defined according to the ARIA guidelines (Bousquet 2008). 
Food allergy was defined as doctor diagnosed food allergy, combined with sensitisation to food allergens. 
Eczema was defined according to the Williams UK Working Party's criteria (William 1994).

characteristics.name: Notes
characteristics.value:
Sponsor: declared independent study. 1  author employee of probiotic manufacturer (Winclove Bio Industries B.V., Amsterdam). 

Outcomes of allergic disease at 6 years of age included in analysis under childhood incidence.

Declaration of interests: HT was an employee of Winclove Bio Industries and the University Medical Centre Utrecht. All of the other authors declared that they had no conflict of interest.

risk-of-bias.domain: Bias due to deviations from intended interventions
risk-of-bias.support-for-judgement:
Placebo consisted of the carrier of the probiotic bacteria mixture - rice starch and maltodextrin. Both supplements were dispensed as a stable powder in identical individually packed sachets containing 3 g of material.

Double Blind (Participant, Caregiver, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor).

risk-of-bias.domain: Bias due to missing outcome data
risk-of-bias.support-for-judgement: 58/156 (37%) post-randomisation losses - 54 exclusion criteria, 21 parental requests, 8 (all control group) excluded due to non-compliance. Completed study at 2 years: probiotic group 50/78 (64%); placebo group 48/78 (62%). 83 participants of the former P and A study participated in the follow-up study at the age of 6 years: probiotic group 39, placebo group 44. High drop-out right, although described to not be related to study intervention.

risk-of-bias.domain: Bias in measurement of the outcome
risk-of-bias.support-for-judgement: Primary outcomes: Incidence and severity of atopic disease at the age of 2 years. Incidence and prevalence of eczema at 2 years. Specific definitions for allergic disease or food hypersensitivity, or both, reported. Not all infants with parental reported eczema examined by physician.

risk-of-bias.domain: Bias in selection of the reported result
risk-of-bias.support-for-judgement: No prespecified analysis plan. NCT00200954.

risk-of-bias.domain: Overall bias
risk-of-bias.support-for-judgement: The study is judged to have some concerns for multiple domains in a way that substantially lowers confidence in the result.

risk-of-bias.domain: Bias arising from the randomization process
risk-of-bias.support-for-judgement:
Block randomisation with a block size of 10 was used. Method of sequence generation not reported. Statistically significant imbalance between groups in frequency of pets at home.

Study investigators ensured that randomisation was successful with placebo and intervention groups being equal with respect to potential risk factors and confounders. Allocation concealment method not described. 54/156 excluded after randomisation as met exclusion criteria.

references.title: Specific probiotics in reducing the risk of acute infections in infancy – a randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled study

characteristics.name: Notes
characteristics.value:
Sponsor: funded by the Microbes and Man Research Program, Academy of Finland, and the Sigrid Juselius Foundation.

Declaration of interest: not reported.

characteristics.name: Outcomes
characteristics.value:
Primary outcomes: effects of probiotic supplementation in reducing the risk of infectious disease in infants devoid of the recommended 6 months of exclusive breast-feeding.


Other outcomes: clinical examination at 3, 7, and 12 months. Skin prick test performed at ages 7 and 12 months. 
 

Definitions

Atopic eczema: criteria introduced by Hanifin and Rajka (Hanifin 1980).
Cow’s milk hypersensitivity: Confirmed by double-blind, placebo-controlled cow’s milk challenge. CMA confirmed by SPTs at the ages of 7 and 12 months.

characteristics.name: Interventions
characteristics.value:
81 infants randomised to receive infant formula (Enfamil, Mead Johnson Nutritionals, Evansville, IN) supplemented with either:
Treatment (n = 38): 1 x 1010 colony-forming units of Lactobacillus rhamnosus (Lactobacillus GG, American type culture collection 53103, Valio Ltd., Helsinki, Finland) and Bifidobacterium lactis Bb-12 (Chr. Hansen, Hoersholm, Denmark) daily until the age of 12 months; or


Control (n = 43): Placebo (microcrystalline cellulose).
The intervention was commenced when the need for artificial feeding arose and the supplemented formula was to be used as the sole infant formula during the study period.

characteristics.name: Participants
characteristics.value:
Inclusion criteria: need for artificial feeding before the age of 2 months. Intervention commenced when the need for artificial feeding arose and the supplemented formula was to be used as the sole infant formula. Not selected on basis of risk of allergy.


Exclusion criteria: infants with chronic disease.

characteristics.value: Randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled clinical trial.

references.authors: Ortiz-Andrellucchi A, Sanchez-Villegas A, Rodriguez-Gallego C, Lemes A, Molero T, Soria A, et al
references.title: Immunomodulatory effects of the intake of fermented milk with Lactobacillus casei DN114001 in lactating mothers and their children

characteristics.name: Methods
characteristics.value: Randomised, controlled, double-blind intervention study with parallel groups.

characteristics.name: Participants
characteristics.value:
Inclusion criteria: pregnant women aged 18 – 40 years in good general health, low obstetric risk with a normal delivery of a healthy baby.

Exclusion criteria: participants  with pre-existing conditions such as diabetes, hypertension, autoimmune diseases, asthma, allergy, renal diseases, hepatic diseases, antecedents of viral, bacterial or protozoan infection, multiple pregnancy, high-risk pregnancy, anaemia with Hb below 10·5% and those who smoked > 10 cigarettes/d.

characteristics.name: Interventions
characteristics.value:
Treatment (n = 59): milk fermented with L. casei DN-114001 consumed 3 times/day for 6 weeks, or

Control (n = 45): placebo (killed L. casei).

Breastfed: probiotic group 92·6%, control group 81·6%.

The administration of the study products consisted of consumption 3 times per day during 6 weeks. Initiation of the fermented milk intake occurred on the day following the first extraction of blood and breast milk samples.

characteristics.name: Outcomes
characteristics.value:
Primary outcomes: to determine if probiotic modulated immune system in women who had recently delivered and were breast-feeding; role of probiotic intake on cytokines in maternal milk and on newborn health variables was also ascertained.


Other outcomes: antropometry, respiratory episodes (cold, otitis, pharyngitis, laryngitis, bronchitis, pneumonia), gastrointestinal symptoms (oral candidiasis, regurgitation, diarrhoea, colic, constipation)

Definitions: evaluated dermatitis and allergic episodes at 2 and 6 months. Definition of dermatitis (communication from author) does not meet review definition for eczema (dermatitis defined as erythematous lesions, with pruritus, presence of cradle cap, peeling and flaking (scaliness or desquamation).

Cow's milk allergy was confirmed by serological test and clinical diagnosis.

Declaration of interests: J.C worked for Danone. None of the other authors had a conflict of interest.

references.authors: Savino F, Cordisco L, Tarasco V, Palumeri E, Calabrese R, Oggero R, et al
references.title: Lactobacillus reuteri DSM 17938 in infantile colic: a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial

characteristics.name: Methods
characteristics.value: Randomised, controlled, double-blind study.

characteristics.name: Participants
characteristics.value:
Inclusion criteria: breastfed infants diagnosed with infantile colic according to modified Wessel’s criteria (Wessel 1954), episodes of fussy crying that lasted 3 hours a day and for 3 days in the 1 week before enrolment.) All were born at term, birth weight: 2500 – 4000 g and aged 2 to 16 weeks.

Exclusion criteria: chronic illness or gastrointestinal disorders, any intake of probiotics or antibiotics in the week preceding recruitment, and any formula-feeding.

characteristics.name: Interventions
characteristics.value:
5 drops, once a day, 30 minutes before the feed in the morning for 21 days:

Treatment (n = 25): L reuteri 108 live bacteria/day in sunflower oil and medium-chain triglyceride oil.

Control (n = 25): placebo (sunflower oil and medium-chain triglyceride oil).

characteristics.name: Outcomes
characteristics.value:
Primary outcome: reduction in average crying time to < 3 hours a day on day 21

Other outcomes: the number of responders in each group on days 7, 14, 21. Intestinal microflora of the infants and any adverse effects.

Definitions: not given.

Adverse events reported included rhinitis and eczema.

Parents recorded diary. Paediatricians assessed baseline and day 21.

characteristics.name: Notes
characteristics.value:
Sponsor: funded by BioGaia AB (Stockholm, Sweden).

Declaration of interests: not reported.

risk-of-bias.domain: Bias due to deviations from intended interventions
risk-of-bias.support-for-judgement:
Bottles were coded and blinded by the study statistician for both the participants and for the physicians, and the code was revealed to the investigators once recruitment, data collection, and all laboratory and statistical analyses were complete.

Follow-up visits performed by the same paediatrician.

Parental interviews, with the aid of a study diary, was used to assess adverse events', such as illness.

Faecal samples collected directly from sample or anus and samples (blinded) were stored (refrigerated) until analysed.

Cause of missing data were similar across both groups.

references.authors: Scalabrin DM, Johnston WH, Hoffman DR, P'Pool VL, Harris CL, Mitmesser SH
references.title: Growth and tolerance of healthy term infants receiving hydrolyzed infant formulas supplemented with Lactobacillus rhamnosus GG: randomized, double-blind, controlled trial

references.authors: Scalabrin D, Harris C, Johnston WH, Berseth CL
references.title: Long-term safety assessment in children who received hydrolyzed protein formulas with Lactobacillus rhamnosus GG: a 5-year follow-up

characteristics.name: Methods
characteristics.value: Double-blind, randomised, controlled, parallel, prospective study.

characteristics.name: Participants
characteristics.value:
Inclusion criteria: eligible infants were healthy, term infants 38 to 42 weeks' gestational age, with birth weight ≥ 2500 g and solely formula-fed at least 24 hours prior to randomisation.

Exclusion criteria: history of underlying disease or congenital malformation likely to interfere with normal growth and development or participant evaluation, formula intolerance, weight at 14 days of age < 98% of birth weight, large for gestational age born from a mother diabetic at childbirth, immunodeficiency, fever at randomisation, systemic antibiotic use within 7 days of randomisation, systemic steroid use any time since birth, LGG-supplemented diet any time since birth (including infants breast-fed when mother consumed dietary LGG), and diarrhoea within 24 hours prior to randomisation.

characteristics.name: Interventions
characteristics.value:
Randomised to receive through 120 days of age:

Control (n = 94): extensively hydrolysed (EH) casein formula (Nutramigen LIPIL, Mead Johnson & Company, Evansville, IN);

Treatment 1 (n = 94): same formula supplemented with LGG 108 cfu per gram of formula powder; or


Treatment 2 (n = 98): partially hydrolysed whey: casein (60:40) formula supplemented with LGG 108 cfu per gram of formula powder.

A subset of infants continued to receive study formula through 150 days of age.

All formulas supplemented with 0.64% arachidonic acid and 0.32% docosahexaenoic acid of total FAs.

characteristics.name: Outcomes
characteristics.value:
Primary outcome: to evaluate the effect on growth and tolerance in healthy, term infants from 14 to 120 days of age.

Other outcomes: to analyse the incidence of allergies and infections as well as allergic sensitisation and antibody response to routine vaccinations in a subset of infants who received study formula up to 150 days of age. Reported percentages of allergy-related events.

Definitions: not given for allergy-related events.

Performed total IgE and specific IgE to cow milk protein by fluorescent EIA. Definitions of allergy-related adverse events not provided in 5 year follow-up study.

characteristics.name: Notes
characteristics.value:
Sponsor: study was supported by Mead Johnson Nutrition.

Adverse events categorised as allergy-related (EHF, 10%; EHF-LGG, 18%; PHF-LGG, 15%). Data not included in meta-analysis.

Allergy-related adverse event through year 5 included in analysis under childhood incidence.

Declaration of interests: DS, CLH and CLB were all employees of Mead Johnson Nutrition at the time of the study. WJ received research support from Mead Johnson Nutrition. No other conflict of interest to disclose.

risk-of-bias.domain: Bias arising from the randomization process
risk-of-bias.support-for-judgement:
Study sponsor created a computer-generated, gender-stratified randomisation schedule, provided in sealed consecutively numbered envelopes, for each study site. On infant enrolment, study formula was assigned by opening the next sequential envelope from the appropriate set at the study site. Demographics and characteristics including family history of allergy were similar for infants in all groups at enrollment.

Parents or guardians provided written informed consent prior to enrolment. Details of allocation concealment not provided.

characteristics.name: Methods
characteristics.value: Double-blind, placebo-controlled randomised clinical trial.

characteristics.name: Participants
characteristics.value:
Families with a history of allergic disease were recruited from the antenatal clinics.

Inclusion criteria: first-degree relative with doctor diagnosis of asthma, allergic rhinitis or eczema and a positive SPT to Dust mites; gestational age >35 weeks; birth weight > 2 kg.

Exclusion criteria: no major congenital malformation or illness. Parents who chose to breast-feed exclusively were not considered for the study.

characteristics.name: Interventions
characteristics.value:
Participants received at least 60 mL (9.26 g) a day of commercially available cow’s milk-based infant formula with:

Treatment (n = 127): probiotic supplementation B. longum BL999 (ATCC: BAA-999 designation BB536, Morinaga, Japan) 1x107 cfu/g and L. rhamnosus LPR (CGMCC 1.3724) 2 x 107 cfu/g initiated within 12 hours for the first 6 months of life; or

Control (n = 126): formula without probiotics.

Mothers were free to decide whether to make up the remainder of the baby feeds with either the trial formula, or to supplement with breast milk, or another infant formula. Weaning to solids was allowed at between 4 and 6 months of age according to local practices, but parents were advised to avoid potentially allergenic foods including eggs, shellfish, and peanuts until after the first birthday.

characteristics.name: Outcomes
characteristics.value:
Primary outcome: prevention of eczema and allergic sensitisation in the first year of life in Asian infants at risk of allergic disease.

Other outcomes: Paediatrician evaluation at 1, 3, 6 and 12 months which involved a detailed history, recording of anthropometric data and clinical examination. Questionnaires are administered at these visits to record clinical disease and environmental exposures. Biweekly phone calls performed for the first 6 months, after which monthly phone contacts were carried out.

Definitions

Eczema defined as a pruritic rash over the face or extensors with a chronic relapsing course criteria of Hanifin and Rajka (Hanifin 1980), or both physician diagnosed at 12 months, SCORAD index used.

Sensitisation: SPTs and specific IgE at 12 months. A weal > 3 mm in diameter above the negative control was considered positive.

characteristics.name: Notes
characteristics.value:
Sponsor: National Medical Research Council, Singapore. The study milk formula was sponsored by Nestles, Vevey, Switzerland.

Infant incidence of cow's milk sensitisation/hypersensitivity unable to be included in analysis due to probiotic n = 0 and placebo n = 0. Incidence of atopic disease up to 5 years included in analysis under childhood incidence. Food allergy since year 3 included in analysis under childhood prevalence.

Declaration of interests: not reported.

risk-of-bias.domain: Bias due to deviations from intended interventions
risk-of-bias.support-for-judgement:
The formula feeds (test and control) tasted and appeared identical.
Mothers (caregivers), doctors, nurses and statisticians involved in the trial were blinded to milk formula allocation.

risk-of-bias.domain: Bias due to missing outcome data
risk-of-bias.support-for-judgement: 8/253 withdrew before follow-up. 10 participants dropped out (probiotic group = 2, placebo group = 8). Analysed at 1 year: probiotic group n = 124, placebo group n = 121). Loss to follow-up: 18/253 (7%). 220/253 (87%) participants completed follow-up until 5 years. Small number of drop outs.

risk-of-bias.domain: Bias in measurement of the outcome
risk-of-bias.support-for-judgement: Primary clinical outcome measure was the incidence of eczema in 1st year; secondary outcome measure allergen sensitisation. Specific definitions for allergy reported.

risk-of-bias.domain: Bias in selection of the reported result
risk-of-bias.support-for-judgement:
Pre-specified analysis plan was not found for follow up at 1yr. Pre-specified analysis plan available for follow up at 5 and 7 years, although no indication of whether there was any deviation from pre-specified plan. NCT00318695, NCT00365469, NCT00826189.
A large number of participants (208/266) continued to consume probiotics of their own accord in the form of milk formula/food/supplements with probiotics. The investigators noted that this was statistically associated with a reduced incidence of asthma and allergic rhinitis at the age of 5 years.

risk-of-bias.domain: Overall bias
risk-of-bias.support-for-judgement: The study is judged to raise some concerns in at least one domain for this result, but not to be at high risk of bias for any domain.

risk-of-bias.domain: Bias arising from the randomization process
risk-of-bias.support-for-judgement:
Sequential computerised randomisation in blocks of 6. Allocation concealment was not specified. 

Well balanced groups after randomisation. No significant differences in the baseline demographics and family history of allergic disease between the participants who completed follow-up and those who were lost to follow-up. Participants in the probiotic group and placebo group that completed the 5 year follow-up did not differ significantly in environmental factors.

Allocation concealment not specified. 

A large number of participants (208/266) continued to consume probiotics of their own accord in the form of milk formula/food/supplements with probiotics. The investigators noted that this was statistically associated with a reduced incidence of asthma and allergic rhinitis at the age of 5 years.

characteristics.name: Methods
characteristics.value: Randomised double-blind, placebo-controlled study.

characteristics.name: Participants
characteristics.value:
Newborn 1-month-old infants were recruited.

Inclusion criteria: the child was healthy, parents were willing to use the novel slow release pacifier and the child started to receive the tablet before the age of 2 months age.

Exclusion criteria: not specified

characteristics.name: Interventions
characteristics.value:
Children were given 2  probiotic tablets per day via a novel slow-release pacifier. Each tablet contained 5 x 109 cfu of BB-12. Until 6 - 8 months of age, children received the tablet via a small pacifier, thereafter via a large pacifier.

Treatment (n = 55): probiotic Bifidobacterium animalis BB-12 containing xylitol tablet administered to the infants twice a day (daily dose BB-12 10 x 109 cfu) from age 1 – 2 months to 8 months.

Control (n = 54): control xylitol tablet.

Exclusive breastfeeding (months - mean (SD)): treatment: 3·4 (1·7); control 3·8 (1·9). The families were encouraged not to use any other pacifier besides the slow-release pacifier twice a week. If families wanted to use a regular pacifier as well, they were offered the pouch-free version of the slow-release pacifier.

characteristics.name: Outcomes
characteristics.value:
Primary outcome: reported cumulative incidence of acute respiratory infections and doctor-diagnosed acute otitis media before age of 8 months. Caries occurrence to 4 years.


Other outcomes: acute infectious diseases to 2 years. Successful intestinal passage of BB-12. Oral microbial colonisation.

Parents reported atopic diseases or allergic sensitisation to 8 months.

Definitions: not reported.

characteristics.name: Notes
characteristics.value:
Sponsor: grants from Emil Aaltonen and Sohlberg Foundations, Finnish Dental Society Apollonia and Finnish Dental Association. Chr. Hansen A/S (Hoersholm, Denmark) donated the BB-12 for the probiotic tablets and helped in carrying out the faecal analysis of BB-12. The tablets were manufactured by Oy Karl Fazer Ab (Vantaa, Finland). The pacifiers manufactured by Mekalasi Oy (Konnevesi, Finland). Neither Hansen, Fazer nor Mekalasi provided financial support.

Declaration of interests: T.T had no conflicts of interest. No other conflict of interest reported.

results.outcome: Cow's milk protein allergy by 2 years

risk-of-bias.domain: Bias due to deviations from intended interventions
risk-of-bias.support-for-judgement: All study personnel and participants were blinded to treatment assignment for the duration of the study.

risk-of-bias.domain: Bias due to missing outcome data
risk-of-bias.support-for-judgement: 69% (75/109) started administration, 38/55 received BB-12 and 37/54 xylitol control. 31% (34/109) were excluded. 69/109 (63%) completed follow-up. Reasons for drop-out was not described. Potentially clinically important differences between groups as analysed after substantial losses.

risk-of-bias.domain: Bias in measurement of the outcome
risk-of-bias.support-for-judgement:
Primary outcomes were assessed using standardised clinical measures.

Breastfeeding habits, pacifier use, dietary habits, medications, and all signs and symptoms of acute infections were registered in diaries by parents and in questionnaires by trained professionals.

risk-of-bias.domain: Bias in selection of the reported result
risk-of-bias.support-for-judgement: Allergic disease was not described as an outcome on pre-specified analysis plan. NCT00638677.

risk-of-bias.domain: Overall bias
risk-of-bias.support-for-judgement: The study is judged to be at high risk of bias in at least one domain for this result.

risk-of-bias.domain: Bias arising from the randomization process
risk-of-bias.support-for-judgement: Computer generated blocks of three. Placebo used. Participants were blinded to treatment assignment. No clear allocation concealment described.

characteristics.name: Notes
characteristics.value:
Sponsor: National Health and Medical Research Council of Australia and Probiomics as an industry partner. The study and all of the analyses were conducted independently of the commercial entity.

Clinical and sensitisation characteristics of the study population at 1 year included in analysis under infant incidence. Clinical and sensitisation at 2.5 years of age included in analysis under childhood incidence. All outcomes described in the 5 year follow-up study refer to "recent" symptoms (in the preceding 12 months) unless stated otherwise; thus included in analysis under childhood prevalence. 

Declaration of interests: not reported.

characteristics.name: Outcomes
characteristics.value:
Primary outcomes: clinical assessment of atopic dermatitis at 6 and 12 months of age. Incidence of atopic dermatitis, food allergy, and sensitisation at 12 months and 2.5 years of age.r Primary allergy prevention in a population of Australian children at high risk of allergic disease.

Other outcomes: detailed history and examination collected at 12 months and 2.5 years by the same paediatric allergist. Other symptoms based on parental record; all parents who noted (quote:) 'noisy breathing' of any kind were asked to give detail descriptions of this to the paediatrician. Doctor diagnosed gastrointestinal infections were recorded. Assessment of the expression of T-regulatory phenotype.

Definitions: 
Atopic dermatitis: typical skin lesions responsive to topical steroids. The severity determined using the severity score of atopic dermatitis (SCORAD).
IgE-mediated food allergy: History of immediate symptoms after contact with or ingestion of food and a positive SPT to the implicated food. Symptoms of acute food allergy include skin reactions (hives, rash or swelling) or respiratory symptoms (cough, wheeze, stridor) or gastrointestinal symptoms (abdominal pain, vomiting, loose stools) or cardiovascular symptoms (collapse).

Asthma: defined as recurrent wheezing (3 or more episodes, at least 1 confirmed by a paediatrician or general practitioner) with evidence of responsiveness to bronchodilator therapy.

characteristics.name: Interventions
characteristics.value:
Treatment (n = 115): 3 x 109 / L acidophilus LAVRI-A1 in maltodextrin (Probiomics, Sydney, Australia). Supplements supplied as stable freeze-dried powder, dissolved in 1 to 2 mL sterile water and administered orally daily from birth to 6 months.


Control (n = 111): maltodextrin alone.


Intervention commenced within 48 hours of delivery and was given only to the baby, independent of feeding method.

characteristics.name: Participants
characteristics.value:
Inclusion criteria: pregnant, atopic women. Maternal atopy defined as doctor-diagnosed clinical history of asthma, allergic rhinitis, or eczema plus a positive SPT to 1 or more common allergens.


Exclusion criteria: women excluded if smoked, had other medical problems or pregnancy complications, delivered before 37 weeks' gestation, or already taking probiotic supplements.

characteristics.name: Methods
characteristics.value: Randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial.

risk-of-bias.domain: Bias due to deviations from intended interventions
risk-of-bias.support-for-judgement: Placebo supplements were image-matched, and participants, research scientists, and paediatrician remained blinded for the duration of the study. Randomisation and allocation of supplements occurred at a separate area from participant recruitment. Supplements were dispensed to participants by persons independent from the allocation process.

risk-of-bias.domain: Bias due to missing outcome data
risk-of-bias.support-for-judgement:
Losses to follow up: 8/226 withdrew prior to receiving allocation. 40/226 discontinued intervention: 2 due to non-compliance/found study too demanding, 4 due to colic or apparent abdominal discomfort in the baby, 2 due to postnatal depression, 4 due to unrelated infant health problems, 2 due to infant refusing to take supplement. 178/226 analysed at 6 and 12 months (probiotic group n = 89, placebo group n = 89) with 48/226 (21%) loss to follow-up/discontinued at 12 months. Additional control infant not reported for atopic eczema. 153/226 analysed at 2.5-year assessment with 73/226 (32%) loss to follow-up at 2.5 years. 123/226 analysed at 5-year assessment (probiotic group n = 66, placebo group n = 57) with 103/226 (45%) loss to follow-up. 

Dropout rate was similar across both groups and no indication that missing data was related to health outcomes.

risk-of-bias.domain: Bias in measurement of the outcome
risk-of-bias.support-for-judgement: Primary outcome atopic dermatitis and food allergy at 6 and 12 months and evidence of allergen sensitisation at 12 months age. Children were clinically evaluated at 5 years of age, including a detailed history, allergy skin prick testing and physical examinations. Specific definitions for allergy reported. Clinical outcomes were evaluated by the same paediatrician at 5 years of age as at the earlier visits (Prof SL Prescott).

risk-of-bias.domain: Bias in selection of the reported result
risk-of-bias.support-for-judgement: No pre-specified analysis plan found. No clinical trial registry number found.

risk-of-bias.domain: Overall bias
risk-of-bias.support-for-judgement: The study is judged to raise some concerns in at least one domain for this result, but not to be at high risk of bias for any domain.

risk-of-bias.domain: Bias arising from the randomization process
risk-of-bias.support-for-judgement:
Computerised randomisation schedule with allocation and dispensing by pharmacy. Groups were stratified and block-randomised according to maternal allergy (asthma compared with other allergies); parity (first child compared with 2 or more children); and paternal allergy (allergy compared with no allergy).

Recruitment before randomisation. Allocation completed by external personnel, independent from the investigators. Significant differences were seen with birth length (P = 0.013) and birth head circumference (P = 0.023) between the 2 groups as analysed. Other baseline characteristics between groups were balanced with no significant differences reported.

references.authors: Vlieger AM, Robroch A, van Buuren S, Kiers J, Rijkers G, Benninga MA, et al
references.title: Tolerance and safety of Lactobacillus paracasei ssp. paracasei in combination with Bifidobacterium animalis ssp. lactis in a prebiotic-containing infant formula: a randomised controlled trial

characteristics.name: Methods
characteristics.value: Randomised controlled trial.

characteristics.name: Participants
characteristics.value:
Inclusion criteria: pregnant mothers, who intended to bottle-feed infants born > 37 weeks' gestation and < 7 days at enrolment (N = 159).

Exclusion criteria: use of antibiotics in the first week, congenital illnesses or malformations and insufficient Dutch language.

characteristics.name: Interventions
characteristics.value:
Infants fed to 3 months with a pre-biotic containing starter formula supplemented with L. paracasei ssp paracasei and B. animalis ssp. lactis or the same formula without probiotics. Parents of the first 80 infants who completed the first part of the study were asked to continue the use of the study formula for another 3 months. Parents received the assigned infant formula with written instructions for its preparation and were advised to feed infants ad libitum during the study period. Solid foods were introduced at the age of 4 months.

Treatment (n = 69): standard milk-based powder formula with GOS 2.4 g/L with B. animalis 1 x 107 cfu/g and L. paracasei 1 x 107 cfu/g;

Control (n = 64): standard milk-based powder formula with GOS 2.4g/L.

characteristics.name: Outcomes
characteristics.value:
Primary outcome: differences in growth parameters at 3 months of age.

Other outcomes: differences in growth parameters at the age of 6 months, differences in stool characteristics (consistency and frequency), crying (h/d), the number of upper respiratory tract infections and gastrointestinal tract infections as diagnosed by the parents, the number of antibiotics and visits to the general practitioner. Adverse effects were recorded including vomiting, diarrhoea, constipation, colic and rash or eczema. Recorded in participant diaries.

Definitions: definitions not specified. In case of serious adverse events, 1 of the paediatricians was contacted to assess the adverse event.

characteristics.name: Notes
characteristics.value:
Sponsor: Financed by Friesland Foods, Leeuwarden, The Netherlands.

Did not report data for allergy. Included data for adverse effects which combines rash with eczema.

Declaration of interests: J. K and R. t. B were employed by the sponsor (Friesland Foods) at the time of the study. All other authors declared that they had no conflict of interest.

risk-of-bias.domain: Bias due to deviations from intended interventions
risk-of-bias.support-for-judgement:
Both formulas had similar taste, smell and colour. Diaries and growth charts were analysed by authors who were all blinded to the treatment arm. 

Compliance was monitored and no major deviations from the protocol were reported.

risk-of-bias.domain: Bias due to missing outcome data
risk-of-bias.support-for-judgement:
159 mothers enrolled. 133 infants allocated to treatment. 7/133 (5%) at 3 months; 33/133 (25%) at 6 months. Unclear timing of exclusions in relation to randomisation. Reasons for drop out include colic, regurgitation, constipation and practical regions. Reasons for drop out and incidence of adverse events were similar in both groups.

Dropout were not related to health outcomes related to the intervention.

risk-of-bias.domain: Bias in measurement of the outcome
risk-of-bias.support-for-judgement:
Recorded adverse events; primary outcomes were pre-specified and analyses followed a planned approach.

Parental-reported episodes of upper respiratory tract infections and gastrointestinal tract infections, number of antibiotics and general practitioner visits were recorded by parents.

risk-of-bias.domain: Bias in selection of the reported result
risk-of-bias.support-for-judgement: No pre-specified analysis plan was available. ISRCTN78225533.

risk-of-bias.domain: Overall bias
risk-of-bias.support-for-judgement: The study is judged to raise some concerns in at least one domain for this result, but not to be at high risk of bias for any domain.

risk-of-bias.domain: Bias arising from the randomization process
risk-of-bias.support-for-judgement:
Computerised random-number generator. Allocation concealment and sequence not reported.

Baseline characteristics, including birth weight, gestational age, and mode of delivery, were similar between the probiotic and control groups. Fewer infants were born by caesarean section in the probiotic group.

characteristics.name: Methods
characteristics.value: Double-blind, placebo controlled, randomised intervention trial

characteristics.name: Participants
characteristics.value:
Inclusion criteria: breastfed healthy, term infants (gestational age 37 – 42 weeks), birthweight > 2500 g, vaginally delivered, had no allergic manifestation or medication.

Exclusion criteria: atopic manifestation or medication that could affect gut microbiota, i.e. antibiotics, or prior probiotic intake.

Infants at high risk of allergy: probiotic group 66%, placebo 61%.

characteristics.name: Interventions
characteristics.value:
Treatment (n = 89): cereals (containing milk proteins) supplemented with Lactobacillus paracasei F19 (one serving contained 1x108 cfu); or

Control (n = 90): Same cereals without LF19 from 4 to 13 months of age. The recommended intake was at least 1  serving of cereals daily until 13 months of age.

Parents were asked to avoid feeding the infant other products with probiotics. There was no interference with dietary habits in other respects.

characteristics.name: Outcomes
characteristics.value:
Primary outcome: daily breastfeedings as long as the infant was breastfed, and any symptoms from the skin or airway. Any allergy or asthmatic symptoms, doctor's diagnosis and prescription and use of any drug or supplement. Days with infectious symptoms, antibiotic prescriptions and IgG antibody responses to Haemophilus influenza type b (Hib), diphtheria and tetanus vaccines. Reported to 13 months.

Definitions:

Eczema defined on the basis of questionnaires and diaries as an itchy rash for at least 2 weeks with typical distribution and dry skin or  doctors diagnosis of eczema, or both.

Asthma and allergic rhino-conjunctivitis: Only doctor diagnosis of asthma or allergic rhino-conjunctivitis were defined as asthma and allergic rhino-conjunctivitis.

Cow milk protein allergy was diagnosed by a physician by an oral food challenge (blinding not reported).

A trial of the effect of probiotics on the development of atopy and eczema in children

characteristics.name: Methods
characteristics.value: Double-blind, randomised placebo-controlled trial.

characteristics.name: Participants
characteristics.value:
Inclusion criteria: pregnant women - the woman or infant’s biological father had a history of treated for asthma, hay fever, or eczema.

Exclusion criteria: planned to move from the study centre during the 2 years study period, delivered < 37 weeks' gestation or had not taken the study probiotic for ≥ 2 weeks pre-birth, already taking probiotic supplements or intended to use these in the child, if infants were < 3rd percentile for weight, had congenital anomalies, infant admission to neonatal unit for more than 48 hours or mother receiving less than 2 weeks of treatment prior to giving birth.

characteristics.name: Interventions
characteristics.value:
Women were randomised to receive daily supplements of either:

Treatment 1 (n = 170): 6 x 109 cfu/day L. rhamnosus HN001; or

Treatment 2 (n = 171): 9 x 109 cfu/day B. animalis (spp lactis HN019); or

Control (n = 171): placebo (dextran, salt and a yeast extract).

Intervention commenced 2 – 5 weeks before delivery, supplementation was continued in the postnatal period for the mother for up to 6 months if breastfeeding and for the baby, independent of feeding methods, for 2 years. Infants started the intervention between 2 and 16 days post-birth, given undiluted to the infant or mixed with water, breast milk, or formula and given via a teaspoon or syringe until solid food was started.

Over 95% breastfed. Mean duration breast feeding 9 months.

characteristics.name: Outcomes
characteristics.value:
Primary outcome: eczema prevalence and severity from birth to 2 years. Skin prick test assessed at 24 months.

Other outcomes: faecal samples collected soon after birth and at 3, 12, and 24 months of age; safety outcomes and standard morphometric measures, frequency and reason for any adverse effects, antibiotic use by the infants over the treatment period

Definitions: eczema prevalence was assessed using a modified version of the UK Working Party’s Diagnostic Criteria (William 1994), for atopic dermatitis at 3, 6, 12, 18 and 24 months via questionnaire and assessment of visible atopic dermatitis. IgE-associated eczema was defined as eczema plus a positive SPT response, and non-IgE associated eczema as eczema plus a negative SPT response.
Atopy was assessed at 24 months using SPTs and defined as any mean wheal diameter > 3 mm.
Allergic disease development (eczema, asthma, rhinoconjunctivitis, and atopic sensitisation) was assessed using SPT, total and serum-specific IgE (ssIgE), to age 6 years.

characteristics.name: Notes
characteristics.value:
Sponsor: Health Research Council of New Zealand and Fonterra Co-operative Group (Auckland, New Zealand).

In this review, infant incidence reports analyses eczema and allergic disease at 2 years of age. Childhood incidence analyses the cumulative prevalence of eczema and allergic disease at 6 years of age. Childhood prevalence analyses the current health outcomes at 6 years. Prevalence of allergic disease measured at 11 years included in analysis under adolescent allergic disease.

Declaration of interests: Wickens received research funding from the Health Research Council and Fonterra Co-operative Group. P.N Black has received research funding from the Health Research Council of New Zealand, the Child Health Research Foundation and Boehringer-Ingelheim T. V. Stanley has received research funding from the Health Research Council of New Zealand and Washington Medical Research Foundation. E. Mitchell has received research funding from the Child Health Research Foundation and the National Heart Foundation of New Zealand and has served as trustee in the past year for the Wilson & Sweet Trust and the Child Health Research Foundation. P. Fitzharris has received research funding from the Marsden Fund and the Foundation for Research, Science & Technology. G. W. Tannock has received research support from the Marsden Fund and the Foundation for Research, Science and Technology. G. Purdie has received research funding from the Health Research Council of New Zealand and the Ministry of Health. J. Crane has received research funding from the Health Research Council of New Zealand, Rex Medical and Asthma and Respiratory Foundation of New Zealand, and the National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences.

risk-of-bias.domain: Bias due to deviations from intended interventions
risk-of-bias.support-for-judgement: All study nurses and participants were blind to treatment assignment for the duration of the study. To evaluate the efficacy of the blinding, the final questionnaire asked participants to indicate whether they believed they were in a probiotic or placebo group.

risk-of-bias.domain: Bias due to missing outcome data
risk-of-bias.support-for-judgement:
Losses to follow up: 66/512 (13%). Loss to follow-up prebirth n = 7, not meeting birth criteria n = 31, lost to follow-up n = 28. 35 discontinuation of intervention. 422/512 participants responded to the 6 year follow up (loss to follow up: 90/512 (18%)); L. rhamnosus group n = 134, B. lactis group n = 144, placebo group n = 144. 342/512 participants completed questionnaire at 11 year follow up (loss to follow up: 170/512 (33%); L. rhamnosus group n = 109, B. lactis group n = 118, placebo group n = 115.

Loss to follow-up and drop out were due to sickness in mother, infant, time management, relocation, unable to be contacted, opposed capsules or declined contact. Reasons were not related to health outcomes measured.

risk-of-bias.domain: Bias in measurement of the outcome
risk-of-bias.support-for-judgement:
Primary outcome cumulative prevalence of eczema by 2 years. Specific definitions for eczema and allergic disease reported.

The research staff were trained in determining eczema by using an internationally recognised training manual for defining atopic eczema (SCORAD). This occurred for all participants regardless of whether they had been diagnosed with eczema. Allergy testing was performed by the study nurse, using a panel of allergens shown to detect 90% of atopic children at 15 months.

risk-of-bias.domain: Bias in selection of the reported result
risk-of-bias.support-for-judgement: Pre-specified analysis plan provided. ACTRN12607000518460.

risk-of-bias.domain: Overall bias
risk-of-bias.support-for-judgement: The study is judged to be at low risk of bias for all domains for this result.

risk-of-bias.domain: Bias arising from the randomization process
risk-of-bias.support-for-judgement:
Performed by clinical trials pharmacist, stratified by study centre and performed in blocks of 15 according to a computer-generated randomisation list.

Well-balanced after randomisation. Differences in participation rates at 11 years by outcomes at 6 years were not significant between study groups.

At enrollment assigned to next sequential study number. Allocation of supplements were performed by external personnel not associated with participants.

references.title: An α-lactalbumin-enriched and symbiotic-supplemented v. a standard infant formula: a multicentre, double-blind, randomised trial

characteristics.name: Methods
characteristics.value: Double-blind randomised controlled trial.

characteristics.name: Participants
characteristics.value:
Inclusion criteria: gestational age > 37 weeks, a postnatal age less than 3 days, fed from birth with probiotic- and prebiotic-free infant formula, and without human milk before inclusion. 4  centres participated in the trial (Mother-and-Children Hospital, Nates, France; Children's Hospital Angers, France; Hospital Saint-Vincent de Paul and HospitalSalpetriere, Paris, France).

Exclusion criteria: infant presenting a metabolic, nervous, digestive or organic disease able to interfere with study, evidence of cow's milk protein allergy, infant presenting lactose intolerance.

characteristics.name: Interventions
characteristics.value:
Treatment (n = 48): the experimental formula was characterised by the presence of 2  strains of probiotics (Lactobacillus rhamnosus LCS-742 and Bifidobacterium longum subsp infantis M63) and by the addition of prebiotics: 96% galacto-oligosaccharides and 4% short-chain fructo-oligosaccharides. This formula was also enriched with bovinea-lactalbumin, using a native whey protein concentrate with high a-lactalbu-min concentration (34% of soluble proteins) obtained using careful fractionation techniques (ultrafiltration). 

Control (n = 49): standard infant formula.

The intervention ended at 6 months of age.

characteristics.name: Outcomes
characteristics.value:
Primary outcomes: antropometric measurements such as weight, length, BMI, and cranial perimeter. Dermatological examination and scoring atopic dermatitis (SCORAD) index calculation, sleeping time and general well-being using structured interviews. 

Other outcomes: formula intake for each meal, bowel habits and stool consistency over the 3 d before each visit were also collected from a home diary kept by the parents. 

Definitions: atopic dermatitis utilised the UK Working Party's diagnostic criteria (William 1994), and SCORAD index was calculated to assess severity.

characteristics.name: Notes
characteristics.value:
Sponsor: study was supported by grants from Sodliac, France. Ordesa Group provided scientific support.

Declaration of interests: J.-C R. and C. D. received consulting fees from Sodilac, France. No other conflicts of interest reported.

risk-of-bias.domain: Bias arising from the randomization process
risk-of-bias.support-for-judgement:
Random sequence generation not discussed. Each product (experimental formula and control formula) was identified by a number randomly allocated using a software. No statistical perinatal characteristics were observed.

After inclusion, infants were randomly assigned to the experimental or control formula.

characteristics.name: Outcomes
characteristics.value:
Primary outcomes: eczema and sensitisation in first 2 years conducted by a paediatrician. SPTs were performed at 6, 12 and 24 months of age. Circulating IgE antibodies to common allergens were assessed at 6, 12 and 24 months of age. Follow up study at 7-years, allergic disease and skin prick test reactivity were assessed.Follow up assessment by research nurse and structured telephone interview up to 2 years. 


Other outcomes: symptoms of allergic disease, adverse events, infections, use of antibiotics and possible confounding factors and inspection of the skin. SCORAD index was used to assess the severity of eczema. Records from primary care units, private paediatricians and the paedatric clinics were examined if parents reported that child had been examined by physician. Outcomes of the study are assessed as per diagnostic criteria described in the study.
 

Definitions: eczema is physician confirmed. SCORAD score used. Defined as pruritic, chronic or chronically relapsing non-infectious dermatitis with typical features and distribution.

Gastrointestinal allergy required vomiting, diarrhoea, or systemic reaction after ingestion of a potentially allergenic food and a confirmation by challenge, unless there was a clear history of a severe systemic reaction. 
Infants were regarded as sensitised if they had at least 1 positive SPT or detectable circulating allergen specific-IgE antibodies, or both.
Allergic disease assessed at 7 years of age (±3 months) included asthma, allergic rhinoconjunctivitis (ARC), allergic urticaria and eczema. 


Asthma diagnosis required at least 1 of following 2 criteria:

  • doctor diagnosis and asthma symptoms or medication, or both, during the last 12 months; and
  • wheeze or nocturnal cough and a positive reversibility test or pathological FENO value, or both. 

Diagnosis of ARC based on standard ISAAC question and required watery discharge at least twice in contact with the same allergen and no sign of infection.
Had symptoms of or has been treated for the actual allergic disease during the last 12 months, or both.

characteristics.name: Interventions
characteristics.value:
Treatment (n = 117): Lactobacillus reuteri 1x108 cfu daily (freeze-dried, suspended in coconut and peanut oil) given to mother for 4 weeks before delivery, mother and baby daily for 12 months after delivery.


Control (n = 115): placebo (same oil).
Co-interventions: infants breast-fed. When weaned, given whey hydrolysate formula to 6 months (both groups).

Mothers were encouraged to breastfeed. At weaning, babies were offered a hypoallergenic whey hydrolysate until 6 months of age.

characteristics.name: Participants
characteristics.value:
Inclusion criteria: families with allergic disease (1 or more family members with eczema, asthma, gastrointestinal allergy, allergic urticaria, or allergic rhinoconjunctivitis) recruited at antenatal clinics.


Exclusion criteria: mother reporting peanut allergy. Infants admitted to neonatal unit in first week. Insufficient compliance led to exclusion of participants from the study.

references.source: Journal of the Korean Society for Applied Biological Chemistry

characteristics.name: Methods
characteristics.value: Randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial.

characteristics.name: Participants
characteristics.value:
Inclusion criteria: pregnant women with a family history of allergic diseases. A family history of allergic diseases defined as:

  • at least 1  parent or older sibling of the foetus had eczema, as confirmed by a paediatric allergist; or
  • 1 of the parents diagnosed with asthma or allergic rhinitis, or both, by a physician, showing house dust mite-specific IgE > 1.0 kU/L by CAP-FEIA immunoassay.

Exclusion criteria:

  • premature babies delivered < 36 weeks of gestation;
  • infants with immune deficiency disease, necrotising enterocolitis, or congenital disorders; or
  • those requiring anticancer treatment or a central venous catheter.

characteristics.name: Interventions
characteristics.value:
Treatment (n = 57): mothers in the probiotic group took a mixture of Bifidobacterium bifidum BGN4 [1.6 x 109 cfu], Bifidobacterium lactis AD011 (1.6 x 109 cfu), and Lactobacillus acidophilus AD031 (1.6 x 109 cfu) in 0.72 g of maltodextrin and 0.8 g of alpha-corn (Bifido Inc., Hongchungun, Korea) once daily from 8 weeks before the expected delivery to 3 months after delivery. Infants were fed the same powder dissolved in breast milk, infant formula, or sterile water from 4 to 6 months of age.

Control (n = 55): mothers and infants in the placebo group took maltodextrin and alpha-corn without probiotic bacteria.

Mean duration exclusive breastfeeding probiotic group 5.97 months and control group 5.26 months.

characteristics.name: Outcomes
characteristics.value:
Primary outcomes: eczema and sensitisation against common food allergens. Infants were followed up to 1 year of age, involving examinations at 3, 6, and 12 months to assess the occurrence of eczema. Venous blood was obtained at 12 months to measure total IgE and specific IgE against common food allergens

Other outcomes: clinical histories such as gestational age, birth weight, caesarean section delivery, mothers age, duration of breastfeeding, diet, fever (‡ 38.5C), respiratory tract infection, hospitalisation, acute gastroenteritis, and use of antibiotics. 


Definitions:

Diagnosis of eczema was confirmed when the skin lesions met the criteria of Hanifin and Rajka (Hanifin 1980).
The severity of eczema was determined using the 'Six Area Six Sign in Atopic dermatitis (SASSAD) score'.
12 months total IgE and specific IgE against common food allergens (egg white, cow's milk, wheat, peanut, soybean, and buckwheat) using CAP-FEIA (Pharmacia, Uppsala, Sweden). Antigen-specific IgE levels > 0.35 kU/L were considered positive. Probable egg allergy defined when the egg white-specific IgE level ≻ 2 kU/L. IgE associated eczema reported. However, antigen-specific results not reported for symptomatic infants.

characteristics.name: Notes
characteristics.value:
Sponsor: no commercial sponsor reported. Supported by grants (A060546 and A080664) from the Ministry for Health, Welfare and Family Affairs, Republic of Korea.

Declaration of interests: not reported.

risk-of-bias.domain: Bias due to deviations from intended interventions
risk-of-bias.support-for-judgement:
Placebo used. The placebo looked, smelled and tasted identical to the probiotic. Participants were blinded. 

Diagnosis and clinical assessment of eczema was performed by a paediatric allergist who remained unaware of the actual treatment administered during the entire study period.

risk-of-bias.domain: Bias due to missing outcome data
risk-of-bias.support-for-judgement: 68/112 (61%) followed to 12 months. 23 participants dropped out before the 3 month follow-up due to declined participation, non-feeding, administration of other probiotic product outside of study, loss connection; 21 infants discontinued the study after 3 months for declined participation, poor compliance, loss connection, non-administration of probiotic or placebo. High number of drop out is of concern although the reasons were described to be unrelated to study intervention. In the later group, the occurrence of eczema was 20.0% (2/10) in the probiotic group and 54.5% (6/11) in the placebo group at their last visit.

risk-of-bias.domain: Bias in measurement of the outcome
risk-of-bias.support-for-judgement: Primary outcome eczema and sensitisation against common food allergens. Specific definitions for eczema and allergic disease reported.

risk-of-bias.domain: Bias in selection of the reported result
risk-of-bias.support-for-judgement: No pre-specified analysis plan. ISRCTN26134979.

risk-of-bias.domain: Overall bias
risk-of-bias.support-for-judgement: The study is judged to have some concerns for multiple domains in a way that substantially lowers confidence in the result.

risk-of-bias.domain: Bias arising from the randomization process
risk-of-bias.support-for-judgement:
Allocated by trials co-ordinator according to computerised randomisation. The groups were stratified and block-randomised in accordance with:

  • maternal allergy (allergy compared with no allergy);
  • older siblings eczema; and
  • number of parents affected by allergic disease (1 compared with 2).

Potentially clinically significant although not statistically significant differences between groups after randomisation in rates of caesarean delivery and duration of breastfeeding.

Treatment allocated by trials co-ordinator without detailed knowledge of the clinical history. Allocation was not completed by an external personnel.

characteristics.name: Methods
characteristics.value: Randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled study.

characteristics.name: Participants
characteristics.value:
Inclusion criteria: pregnant women with at least 1 parent of the unborn child had a physician-diagnosed allergic disease.
Exclusion criteria: infants born < 37 weeks' gestation, infants with major malformations, and B-twins.

characteristics.name: Interventions
characteristics.value:
Treatment (n = 610): mothers took 1 capsule for 2 - 4 weeks before delivery containing Lactobacillus rhamnosus GG (ATCC 53103), 5 x 109 cfu; L rhamnosus LC705 (DSM 7061), 5 x 109 cfu; Bifidobacterium breve Bb99 (DSM 13692), 2 x 108 cfu; and Propionibacterium freudenreichii ssp. shermanii JS (DSM 7076), 2 x 109 cfu. Their newborn infants received 1 opened capsule containing the same probiotic mixed with 20 drops of sugar syrup containing 0.8 g of galacto-oligosaccharides once daily for 6 months after birth.
Control (n = 613): placebo group mothers and infants took capsules containing microcrystalline cellulose, and infants received sugar syrup without galacto-oligosaccharides.


Exclusive breast-fed treatment group 2.6 months, control group 2.4 months. Standard adapted cow’s milk–based formula replaced breast milk when breast-feeding was insufficient. The use of hypoallergenic formula was restricted to infants allergic to cow’s milk.

characteristics.name: Outcomes
characteristics.value:
Primary outcomes: any allergic disease (food allergy, eczema, asthma, and allergic rhinitis) and IgE-associated (atopic) disease at 2 years.
Other outcomes: eczema and sensitisation. Physician assessment at 3, 6, 24 months and 5 years. At 10 years parents completed questionnaires based on the ISAAC study. At 13 years, follow-up questionnaire was completed.

Definitions
Food allergy diagnosed with an open food challenge.
Eczema: according to the UK Working Party’s criteria (an itchy skin condition plus ≥ 3 of atopic disease in the family, dry skin during the last year, history of eczema, or visible eczema involving typical sites), (William 1994).
Atopic eczema: if IgE associated.
Severity of eczema evaluated using SCORAD score.
Asthma: 2 or more physician-diagnosed wheezing episodes accompanied by persistent cough or exercise-induced symptoms.

characteristics.name: Notes
characteristics.value:
Sponsor: grants from Valio Ltd; 2 authors employed by Valio Ltd.

2023 update: Inclusion of results from 5-year, 10-year, and 13-year follow-up studies. Childhood incidence analysis included results from 5-year follow-up. Childhood prevalence analysis included new onset of allergic disease and eczema diagnosed at age 5 - 10 years (ISAAC based). Adolescent allergic disease included allergic disease present at 13 years of age (12 mo ISAAC based).  

Declaration of interests: K. Kukkonen has received grant support from Valio Ltd. R. Korpela and T. Tuure are employed by Valio Ltd and by R&D. T. Poussa has consultant arrangements with Valio Ltd. M. Kuitunen has received grant support from Valio Ltd. The rest of the authors have declared that they have no conflict of interest.

risk-of-bias.domain: Bias arising from the randomization process
risk-of-bias.support-for-judgement:
Computer-generated block randomisation. No significant differences at baseline between groups in family history of atopy. Intervention and control group remain well-balanced throughout follow-up studies.

Randomisation to probiotic and placebo groups occurred at 35 gestational weeks, prior to birth of infant. Randomisation code was kept by the database consultant and revealed only to the statistician.

references.authors: Hascoët JM, Hubert C, Rochat F, Legagneur H, Gaga S, Emady-Azar S, et al
references.title: Effect of formula composition on the development of infant gut microbiota
references.source: Journal of Pediatric Gastroenterology and Nutrition

characteristics.name: Methods
characteristics.value: Randomised, double-blind, controlled trial.

characteristics.name: Participants
characteristics.value:
Inclusion criteria: healthy, full-term infants whose mothers had chosen to feed their infants exclusively with either breast milk or with formula starting from day 7 of birth until they were 4 months old. Infants had to be ≤ 7 days old at enrollment, weigh between 2500 and 4500 g, and be singletons. 

Exclusion criteria: congenital illnesses or malformations that could affect normal growth; significant prenatal or postnatal disease or both; been rehospitalised for more than 2 days in the first 14 days of life (with the exception of infants that were rehospitalised because of jaundice); received antibiotics prenatally, at the time of enrollment, or during the 5 days preceding enrollment; received probiotic- or prebiotic-containing formulas at the time of enrollment. Caregivers who were not expected to comply with the study requirements. Infants participating in a different study were excluded.

characteristics.name: Interventions
characteristics.value:
Study formula group (n = 39): study formula with low protein and phosphate content, high lactose and contained predominantly whey protein was given to infants from birth to 4 months of age. 

Study formula + BL999 (n = 40): study formula with low protein and phosphate content, high lactose and contained predominantly whey protein supplemented with 2 × 107 colony-forming units (CFU)/g of B longum, strain BL999 (ATCC: BAA-999 designation BB536, Morinaga, Japan; NCC3001) was given to infants from birth to 4 months of age. 

Control formula (n = 38): control formula was given to infants from birth to 4 months of age. 

Breast-fed (n = 73): infants exclusively breastfed from birth to 4 months of age.

characteristics.name: Outcomes
characteristics.value:
Primary outcome: bifidobacterial counts at the 2-month visit. 

Secondary outcomes: non-Bifidobacteria bacterial counts, weight, length, head circumference, digestive tolerance, stool IgA, and the occurrence of adverse events. 

Definitions: adverse events were defined as illnesses or signs and symptoms of illnesses that occurred or worsened during the course of the study. Specific definitions for allergy-skin problems not included.

characteristics.name: Notes
characteristics.value:
Sponsor: Nestlé, Konolfingen, Switzerland was the sponsor of the study and also manufactured the formulas. 

Only infants in the study formula group and study formula + BL999 group have been included for analysis in this review. (Quote:) "Allergy-skin problems" data points included in the analysis as eczema.

Declaration of interest: PGS is an employee of Nestlé Nutrition, Nestec Ltd. The other authors reported no conflicts of interest.

risk-of-bias.domain: Bias due to deviations from intended interventions
risk-of-bias.support-for-judgement:
Control formula used. All 3 formulas in the study contained proteins, carbohydrates, fats, minerals, and vitamins in quantities that provided full nutritional support for infants from birth up to 4 months of age.

Double-blinded study. Control formula used. Formulas were manufactured and blinded by the sponsor, which was the only party with knowledge of the product codes.

risk-of-bias.domain: Bias due to missing outcome data
risk-of-bias.support-for-judgement: Loss to follow-up: 27 (17%) were withdrawn before the end of the study, data from these infants were used when available; only reason for discontinuation was non-compliance - i.e. the family did not arrive for the study visit—and rates were similar in both groups. None of the drop-outs had shown signs of atopic disease before discontinuation.

risk-of-bias.domain: Bias in measurement of the outcome
risk-of-bias.support-for-judgement: The primary aim of the study was to compare the bifidobacterial counts of infants fed different formulas and breastfed. Specific definitions for allergy-skin problems was not included.

risk-of-bias.domain: Bias in selection of the reported result
risk-of-bias.support-for-judgement: No pre-specified analysis plan. No clinical trial registry provided.

risk-of-bias.domain: Overall bias
risk-of-bias.support-for-judgement: The study is judged to raise some concerns in at least one domain for this result, but not to be at high risk of bias for any domain.

risk-of-bias.domain: Bias arising from the randomization process
risk-of-bias.support-for-judgement:
Stratified randomisation was performed using SAS version 8.2 (SAS Institute, Cary, NC). Stratification was based on sex and mode of delivery (caesarean section vs vaginal birth). Study formula and study formula groups were well balanced.
Double-blind, controlled trial. Stratified randomisation was managed by sponsor - Nestle. Details of allocation concealment not described.

references.source: International Archives of Allergy and Immunology

references.authors: Fikri B, Tani Y, Nagai K, Sahara M, Mitsuishi C, Togawa Y, et al
references.title: Soluble CD14 in breast milk and its relation to atopic manifestations in early infancy

references.authors: Dissanayake E, Tani Y, Sahara M, Mitsuishi C, Nagai K, Sato Y, et al
references.title: Skincare and synbiotics for the prevention of atopic dermatitis or food allergy in newborn infants: a 2 × 2 factorial randomized non-treatment controlled trial

characteristics.name: Methods
characteristics.value: 2 × 2 factorial, randomised, non-treatment controlled trial.

characteristics.name: Participants
characteristics.value:
Inclusion criteria: families who attended the antenatal clinic were recruited into the study. Following delivery, the babies were recruited if they were born at term and written informed consent was available from parent(s)/guardian. A family history of atopy was not required for inclusion. 

Exclusion criteria: infants born pre-term, experience complications due to severe underlying disease were excluded from the study. HBV or HIV positivity of mother at the time of birth or any other inappropriate status as judged by the physician.

characteristics.name: Interventions
characteristics.value:
Synbiotic and skincare (n = 137): combination of 0.5 g (7 × 109 CFU/g) of Bifidobacterium bifidumOLB6378 (Meiji Holdings Co. Ltd., Japan) combined with 0.5 g of fructo-oligosaccharides (Meiji Food Materia Co., Ltd., Japan) twice a day and Locobase® REPAIR Cream (Daiichi Sankyo, Japan) which contains ceramide, cholesterol, and free fatty acids 2 - 3 times a day. Intervention was carried out from birth to 6 months of age. 

Synbiotic only (n = 137): combination of 0.5 g (7 × 109 CFU/g) of Bifidobacterium bifidumOLB6378 (Meiji Holdings Co. Ltd., Japan) combined with 0.5 g of fructo-oligosaccharides (Meiji Food Materia Co., Ltd., Japan) 2x a day from birth to 6 months of age. 

Skincare only (n = 138): locobase® REPAIR Cream (Daiichi Sankyo, Japan) which contains ceramide, cholesterol, and free fatty acids 2 - 3 times a day from birth to 6 months.

Control (n = 137): the control group did not receive any synbiotics. The no treatment group was not prevented from applying emollients due to ethical reasons.

characteristics.name: Outcomes
characteristics.value:
Primary outcome: development of atopic dermatitis by 1 year of age. 

Secondary outcome: prevalence of food allergy. Sensitisation to food or inhalant allergens or both. EASI score examined by a paediatrician. 

Definitions: atopic dermatitis was diagnosed according to the criteria of the Japanese Dermatological Association (Katayama 2017), and using the UK Working Party's Diagnostic Criteria (William 1994), included in the questionnaire at 1 year. Defined as itchy rash lasting 2 or more months was reported in the questionnaires returned at 1, 6, and 9 months and 1 year of the baby’s age. 

Food allergy reported in the questionnaire at 1 year. Sensitisation to food or inhalant allergens in total, or both, and allergen-specific IgE levels in blood sampled at 9 months of age.

characteristics.name: Notes
characteristics.value:
Sponsor: supported by the Environmental Restoration and Conservation Agency of Japan in fiscal years 2014 - 2016. Grants from the Japan Agency for Medical Research and Development.

The incidence of AD at 1 year according to the UKWP diagnostic criteria has been used for analysis in this review.

Declaration of interest: no conflicts of interest to disclose

risk-of-bias.domain: Bias arising from the randomization process
risk-of-bias.support-for-judgement:
Babies born at term were randomised into 4 groups according to gender (male or female), mode of delivery (vaginal or caesarean) and family history of allergic diseases (present or absent) using computerised random numbers. Randomisation was performed at a central location.</p><p>Baseline characteristics were similar amongst the groups. Although the number of babies with no family history of allergic disease in the no-intervention group was relatively higher than in the other groups, the investigators found that the difference was not significant.

Intervention group allocation was determined by a randomisation system based on the minimisation technique (Nouvelle Place Inc., Tokyo, Japan).
